Recommended Movies

Recommended Historical Dramas

All the President’s Men: Robert Redford and Dustin Hoffman star in Alan Pakula’s Academy Award-winning 1976 political thriller, based on Washington Post journalists Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward’s book about their investigation of the Watergate scandal, which brought down the Nixon administration.

Daughters of the Dust: Three generations of an African-American family prepare to leave their island home on the Georgia coast and migrate north, leaving behind their unique culture and creole language developed over centuries, in Julie Dash’s award-winning historical drama set in 1902 about her family’s migration to New York.

Fall of the Roman Empire: Anthony Mann’s 1964 historical epic, set in the second century A.D., dramatizes the infighting in the Roman imperial family’s inner circle that led to the murder of Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius and the eventual collapse of the government.

Frost / Nixon: An Australian talk show host takes on President Richard Nixon in a series of interviews in 1977 illuminating Nixon’s role in the 1972 Watergate scandal that led to his resignation, in Ron Howard’s 2008 historical drama.

Gandhi: Ben Kingsley stars in Richard Attenborough’s 1982 multiple Academy Award-winning epic biography of Mahatma Gandhi, the leader of Indian nationalism who used nonviolent civil disobedience to win self-rule and to improve the lives of Indians, including ending untouchability.

Get on the Bus: Spike Lee’s 1996 drama explores the racial, political and religious views of a diverse group of African-American men on a cross-country bus trip to attend the Million Man March in Washington, D.C., called by religious leader Louis Farrakhan to draw attention to African-American social issues.

Good Night, and Good Luck: In 1953 American, respected TV newsman Edward Murrow effectively discredited the fear-mongering tactics and communist witch hunt of U.S. Sen. Joseph McCarthy. George Clooney’s critically acclaimed 2005 drama about media responsibility intercuts beautifully filmed black and white images with historical footage, including shots of Robert Kennedy who was a staff member on McCarthy’s subcommittee.

Hunger: IRA political prisoners protest abusive conditions in the Maze Prison in British director Steve McQueen’s 2008 award-winning historical drama about the 1981 Irish hunger strike.

Judgement at Nuremberg: The post-World War II Nuremberg Trial that prosecuted German judges during the Nazi regime is the focus of Stanley Kramer’s 1961 award-winning courtroom drama featuring an all-star cast.

King’s Speech: As second in line for the throne, soon-to-be King George VI overcomes a stutter with the help of an Australian speech therapist, who helps him deliver his first wartime radio broadcast after his brother abdicates, in British director Tom Hooper’s 2010 multiple Academy Award-winning historical drama.

Last King of Scotland: The fictional story of a Scottish doctor who becomes Ugandan dictator Idi Amin’s physician includes factual events from the general’s 1970s reign, in Scottish director Kevin MacDonald’s 2006 award-winning British drama, based on Giles Foden’s novel.

Long Walk Home: The 1955 Montgomery Bus Boycott in Alabama to end racial segregation of public transportation galvanized the civil rights movement. Whoopi Goldberg stars in Richard Pearce’s 1990 film as a maid who walks to work in protest of Alabama’s segregation laws, and Sissy Spacek stars as her boss who joins a carpool group to drive protesting African Americans to work.

Milk: Sean Penn stars in Gus Van Sant’s 2008 biography of 1970s gay rights activist and politician Harvey Milk, who was the first openly gay person elected in California. The film opens with archival footage of Sen. Dianne Feinstein announcing to the press that City Supervisor Milk and San Francisco Mayor George Moscone were assassinated by disgruntled Supervisor Dan White.

Mississippi Burning: Two FBI agents investigate the 1964 murders of civil rights workers in Mississippi in Alan Parker’s 1988 Academy Award-winning fictionalized historic thriller.

The Queen: Helen Mirren won multiple Best Actress awards for her portrayal of Queen Elizabeth, who was criticized for her handling of the aftermath of Princess Diana’s death in 1997, in Stephen Frears' 2006 British drama.

Quiz Show: The rigged TV quiz show scandals of the 1950s investigated by a Congressional committee are the subject of Robert Redford’s critically acclaimed historical drama, based on Richard Goodwin’s memoir, Remembering America: A Voice from the Sixties.

Right Stuff: Philip Kaufman’s 1983 multiple-Academy Award-winning aeronautical drama features thrilling flight footage, and is based on Tom Wolfe’s best-selling 1979 book about military test pilots who manned the first American spaceflight.

~~ descriptions compiled by Miriam Jacobson
